Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Online Game to Assess and Improve Behavioral Readiness and Social Emotional Skills for Students in Kindergarten and First Grades
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will advance understanding of how game-based methods can be effectively used to help schools bring social emotional learning (SEL) instruction to all students. The end goal of this SBIR project is to create and test a game-based intelligent social tutoring system (ISTS) that both assesses and improves the behavioral readiness and social emotional (SE) skills of Kindergarten and 1st grade (K1) students. SEL is a critically important component of early education for all students, and efforts to bring SEL to the nation?s vulnerable early learners would be particularly impactful, especially in helping to foster equity in academic achievement. The proposed system will guide early learners to learn, and then practice SEL skills in controlled, engaging social simulations. This will provide schools with an easily administered, scalable tool to fill a niche for which there is considerable market pull. In addition to addressing significant societal and market needs, research findings from this SBIR will be used to more broadly inform the efforts of the game development community.

As a first step in this R&D effort, this SBIR Phase I project will (a) develop a game prototype consisting of six game-based scenes designed to assess essential SE skills linked in the literature to school readiness and positive behavioral functioning for young students (e.g., Emotion Regulation, Empathy, Impulse Control); (b) conduct game prototype test groups with K1 students to assess the usability and acceptability of the game as well as gather independent parent ratings and behavioral observations of children's SE skills; (c) develop prototype educator dashboard materials for administration of the SEL game with students, including resources to reinforce and extend SEL beyond the game; and (d) conduct a test of the game and dashboard prototypes with teachers and other educators who represent likely purchasers and/or users of the product with students to assess the feasibility and potential value of the proposed product.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this SBIR project, Personalized Learning Games, Inc. proposed to create and test Zoo Academy™, a game-based intelligent tutoring system (ITS) that both assesses and improves the social emotional (SE) skills and behavioral readiness of K-1 students. Each student will create a personalized avatar and be challenged with a series of virtual social scenarios. Through proprietary scoring algorithms and in-game response comparisons against research samples, our ITS will enable K-1 educators (end users) to proactively and reliably identify students in need of additional support and apply personalized, effective social emotional learning (SEL) intervention with their students through an engaging, scalable, and affordable game-based program. Educators will also have access to a wealth of data tracking, reporting, and implementation support materials through their online educator dashboard.

During Phase I, we completed all four proposed technical objectives, specifically:

(1) Created Game Prototype. As proposed, we developed a Phase I game prototype consisting of an avatar builder to enable students to customize the look of their in-game character (i.e., representation of self within the game) and six social problem solving (SPS) scenes. These six scenes present SPS tasks of moderate difficulty in which students must use SE skills to successfully navigate story-based social scenarios. The data gathered through these scenes is used to determine the student’s baseline skill level for each of our targeted SE skills (i.e., Impulse Control, Emotion Regulation, Social Initiation, Communication, Cooperation, and Empathy) and calibrate the software’s initial student model (which determines the difficulty and pedagogical assistance level presented to the student when completing subsequent skill building scenes). In Phase I, we successfully developed fully functioning versions of these six calibration scenes, including all needed graphics (backgrounds, animals, non-player characters), animations, audio files using professional voice actors, scripts for realistic storylines that adapt to choices the student makes in the game, and mapping of student in-game actions to scoring algorithms based on the importance of each student choice for a given SE skill.

(2) Tested Game Prototype with Students. Initially, we gathered feedback from 20 K-1 students on potential art styles and game mechanics via ratings and discussion groups. We used this student input to select the story narrative, art style (e.g., use of baby animals), game mechanics (e.g., picture menu choices), and name for this new K-1 game (Zoo Academy[1]). Then, after fully developing the game prototype, we conducted test groups with 45 K-1 students to collect observations and parent ratings of students’ social emotional competence, gameplay data and observations, and student feedback and ratings of their experience with the prototype.

(3) Developed Educator Dashboard Prototype. As proposed, we created a set of prototype materials for the online educator dashboard, including prototype data dashboard for real-time visualization of student progress and SE skill mastery, sample reports of student progress, and sample supplemental resources for educators to support implementation and use of our innovation in K-1 classrooms.

(4) Tested Feasibility with End Users. The last task of Phase I was to assess the feasibility and potential value of Zoo Academy with educators who are likely to purchase and/or use the product with students. Although we proposed this test with 40 K-1 teachers and elementary student services support staff (school counselors, psychologists, behavior specialists), we increased our educator sample size to 126 due to the overwhelmingly positive response to our recruitment efforts. Participants reviewed each student and educator component for the prototype and provided quantitative and qualitative feedback. 3. PHASE I WORK PLAN

 

 

Each of these Phase I objectives was successfully completed, and the research with both K-1 students and educators produced compelling evidence that we can achieve our broader innovation R&D goals. Below is a brief summary of key results (complete details follow in subsequent sections).

  • Zoo Academy’s composite assessment of children’s social skill performance was significantly correlated with two independent measures external to the game.
  • The six independent social skill scores that contribute to this composite showed high internal consistency (Cronbach’s alpha =.82). 
  • We found significant grade differences where 1st graders scored higher than kindergarteners. 
  • We saw no significant gender or race subgroup differences in game performance, supporting our goal for an assessment free of bias. 
  • When we asked 126 educators if “I would like to use a game like this as an SEL teaching tool with my students”, 120 (96%) responded ‘Agree’ or ‘Strongly Agree’ (mean score 4.5 / 5).
